title: As South Carolina Votes, Hillary Clinton’s Southern Firewall Appears Poised to Pass First Test
authors: Colleen Mccain Nelson, Valerie Bauerlein, Peter Nicholas, Colleen.Nelson Wsj.Com, Valerie.Bauerlein Wsj.Com, Peter.Nicholas Wsj.Com
content:
COLUMBIA , S.C.—Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders made their final pitches to voters in South Carolina , where a strong showing by Mrs. Clinton , who has a double-digit lead in the polls , could hint at more struggles for Mr. Sanders .
South Carolina Democratic Party officials are expecting a good turnout during Saturday ’ s voting . Democratic Party Chairman Jamie Harrison said this week he is expecting between 350,000 and 400,000 voters to cast ballots . South Carolina polls will close at 7 p.m. EST .
But turnout was sparse midday at the polling location at Columbia ’ s Forest Lake Park .
Some voters were still weighing their options as they headed to cast their ballots . Rana Davis , 52 years old , was torn as she walked from her car to the polling location , saying she supports Mr. Sanders but isn ’ t convinced the Vermont senator could beat Donald Trump if the billionaire businessman emerges as the Republican nominee .
“ I probably will vote for Hillary , ” Ms. Davis said , sounding somewhat resigned .
But the real-estate agent from Columbia had a change of heart at the ballot box . She emerged a few minutes later after casting a vote for Mr. Sanders .
“ I was standing there , and I said , ‘ I ’ ve just got to go with who I believe in , ’ ” Ms. Davis said . “ That ’ s Bernie Sanders . ”
Meanwhile , Alexia Teachey , a 19-year-old student at Benedict College , a historically black college in Columbia , voted for Mrs. Clinton at her school ’ s student center . Ms. Teachey said it didn ’ t make much difference that Mrs. Clinton would be the first woman president , but rather that she is the most aligned with President Barack Obama . “ I like the idea that she ’ s carrying on Obama ’ s legacy , ” she said .
Volunteers for both candidates knocked on doors and waved signs throughout the state ’ s capital on the sunny Saturday , in a last-minute rush to get their voters to the polls .
Korey Te Hira , a 25-year-old financial planner from New Zealand , said he came from across the ocean to volunteer because the selection of the next president has international implications . He said Mrs. Clinton “ makes a lot of common sense ” and that her foreign-policy credentials outweighed Mr. Sanders ’ .
“ You look at the Republican side , it ’ s like a madhouse , ” he said . “ It ’ s not just bad for America , but potentially for the rest of the world . ”
Across town , Sanders campaign volunteer Roger Bouchard , 60 , had knocked on 49 doors by 11 a.m. and found 19 strong Sanders backers .
Although polls showed Mrs. Clinton with a commanding lead in South Carolina , Mr. Bouchard was predicting a Sanders surge and a primary surprise .
“ I think the polls are way off , ” he said . “ This is such a grass-roots effort . ”
On Friday night , Mrs. Clinton held an outdoor rally in Columbia , where she pledged to build on Mr. Obama ’ s legacy . “ We have work to do , but I ’ m excited about what we can do together , ” she told the crowd .
She said the South Carolina primary is personally important to her and that she wants to send “ a strong signal ” Saturday that the state is ready for change .
Former President Bill Clinton joined his wife on the trail Friday evening , calling their time in South Carolina a homecoming and telling voters that they can “ change the future of this country by voting for Hillary . ”
Mrs. Clinton , whose Southern firewall appears poised to pass its first test , has an eye on the Southern states that will vote on Super Tuesday , including Alabama , Georgia , Tennessee , Texas , Arkansas and Virginia .
Her strength in the region , particularly among its many African-American Democratic voters , has been magnified by the Sanders campaign ’ s decision not to try to match her investment here and elsewhere . Officials in some Super Tuesday states say they still are looking for indications that he is competing in the so-called SEC primary .
A march outside a downtown Nashville coffee shop on Saturday will feature a half-dozen , life-size Bernie Sanders cutouts , but otherwise , there has been little sign of Mr. Sanders himself in Tennessee , Democrats said .
“ You kind of get the feel that he doesn ’ t think it ’ s worthwhile coming , ” said Randall Rice , head of the Tennessee Democratic County Chairs Association , who is neutral in the race . “ The Bernie group has come in and set up offices , but he ’ s not been here as far as I know . Hillary has been here a few times . ”
Mr. Sanders told supporters at a Friday night rally at the Township Auditorium in Columbia that “ the people have the power in this country . ”
Rapper Killer Mike , who spoke at the rally , said South Carolinians—and particularly black South Carolinians—shouldn ’ t feel pressured to support Mrs. Clinton because others say they should , be it their mother ( “ Walk past her , walk to the polls ” ) or their preacher ( “ Ask him what would Jesus really do. ” ) .
Mr. Sanders was headed to Minnesota and Texas on Saturday to trumpet his free-college-tuition plan , and he won ’ t be in South Carolina when the election results are announced .
Justin Bamberg , one of a handful of black legislators who endorsed Mr. Sanders in South Carolina , said he wishes the Vermont senator could stay for a victory party , but , “ realistically speaking , how can you get everywhere ? You can ’ t . ”
Tharon Johnson , a Democratic strategist who served as the Southern regional director for Mr. Obama ’ s 2012 campaign , said the reason Mr. Sanders isn ’ t spending as much time in South Carolina as Mrs. Clinton “ is because he now knows you have to develop a broad coalition of support in these Southern states , particularly where there ’ s a high minority voting-age population . ”
Tad Devine , a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign , said the senator ’ s best hope of winning South Carolina hinged on nabbing victories in Iowa , New Hampshire and Nevada , the first three contests . Mr. Sanders won the New Hampshire primary , came close in Iowa and lost Nevada . Absent an early trifecta of wins , Mr. Devine said the Sanders campaign now needs to focus on playing the long game and looking ahead to later contests .
“ We still believe we have the best message , and while we had the advantage of having Iowa and New Hampshire the first and second states , she has the advantage of having so many states from the South so early in the process , ” Mr. Devine said . “ She ’ ll gain from that . Once that ’ s over , the ball comes back to our court and we start to move into a number of states ” where they expected to do well .
But between then and now , Mrs. Clinton is likely to secure lopsided victories that illustrate her ability to attract the diverse coalition necessary for a Democratic candidate to win the general election . She also will rack up many delegates in the process .
Mrs. Clinton broke out an all-star team of political office holders to lead statewide door-knocking in Massachusetts this weekend , in what polls suggest is one of the closest contests among the Super Tuesday states . Mrs. Clinton also plans to hold an event Boston on Monday , her campaign said .
Mrs. Clinton ’ s canvassing team included U.S. Sens . Ed Markey ( D. , Mass . ) and Jeanne Shaheen ( D. , N.H. ) ; Massachusetts ’ popular attorney general , Maura Healey ; Boston Mayor Martin J. Walsh ; four U.S. House members from Massachusetts and one from Rhode Island ; and former Philadelphia Mayor Michael Nutter .
Meanwhile , Mr. Sanders ’ s wife , Jane , disputed suggestions that she and her husband haven ’ t spent time in the South or have written off South Carolina or the region , attributing that narrative to what she called Clinton campaign “ spin. ” Mr. Sanders appeared at campaign events in the state on Sunday , Tuesday and Friday , she noted .
“ They spend a lot of time spinning , and so that ’ s not accurate , ” she said . We ’ ve gone to Alabama—we were down there for the 50th anniversary of Selma . ”
This week , though , Mr. Sanders spent most of his time outside of the South , venturing to Massachusetts , Missouri , Illinois , Michigan , Ohio and Oklahoma .
content_original:
COLUMBIA, S.C.—Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders made their final pitches to voters in South Carolina, where a strong showing by Mrs. Clinton, who has a double-digit lead in the polls, could hint at more struggles for Mr. Sanders.

South Carolina Democratic Party officials are expecting a good turnout during Saturday’s voting. Democratic Party Chairman Jamie Harrison said this week he is expecting between 350,000 and 400,000 voters to cast ballots. South Carolina polls will close at 7 p.m. EST.

But turnout was sparse midday at the polling location at Columbia’s Forest Lake Park.

Some voters were still weighing their options as they headed to cast their ballots. Rana Davis, 52 years old, was torn as she walked from her car to the polling location, saying she supports Mr. Sanders but isn’t convinced the Vermont senator could beat Donald Trump if the billionaire businessman emerges as the Republican nominee.

“I probably will vote for Hillary,” Ms. Davis said, sounding somewhat resigned.

But the real-estate agent from Columbia had a change of heart at the ballot box. She emerged a few minutes later after casting a vote for Mr. Sanders.

“I was standing there, and I said, ‘I’ve just got to go with who I believe in,’ ” Ms. Davis said. “That’s Bernie Sanders.”

Meanwhile, Alexia Teachey, a 19-year-old student at Benedict College, a historically black college in Columbia, voted for Mrs. Clinton at her school’s student center. Ms. Teachey said it didn’t make much difference that Mrs. Clinton would be the first woman president, but rather that she is the most aligned with President Barack Obama. “I like the idea that she’s carrying on Obama’s legacy,” she said.

Volunteers for both candidates knocked on doors and waved signs throughout the state’s capital on the sunny Saturday, in a last-minute rush to get their voters to the polls.

Korey Te Hira, a 25-year-old financial planner from New Zealand, said he came from across the ocean to volunteer because the selection of the next president has international implications. He said Mrs. Clinton “makes a lot of common sense” and that her foreign-policy credentials outweighed Mr. Sanders’.

“You look at the Republican side, it’s like a madhouse,” he said. “It’s not just bad for America, but potentially for the rest of the world.”

Across town, Sanders campaign volunteer Roger Bouchard, 60, had knocked on 49 doors by 11 a.m. and found 19 strong Sanders backers.

Although polls showed Mrs. Clinton with a commanding lead in South Carolina, Mr. Bouchard was predicting a Sanders surge and a primary surprise.

“I think the polls are way off,” he said. “This is such a grass-roots effort.”

On Friday night, Mrs. Clinton held an outdoor rally in Columbia, where she pledged to build on Mr. Obama’s legacy. “We have work to do, but I’m excited about what we can do together,” she told the crowd.

She said the South Carolina primary is personally important to her and that she wants to send “a strong signal” Saturday that the state is ready for change.

Former President Bill Clinton joined his wife on the trail Friday evening, calling their time in South Carolina a homecoming and telling voters that they can “change the future of this country by voting for Hillary.”

Mrs. Clinton, whose Southern firewall appears poised to pass its first test, has an eye on the Southern states that will vote on Super Tuesday, including Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Texas, Arkansas and Virginia.

Her strength in the region, particularly among its many African-American Democratic voters, has been magnified by the Sanders campaign’s decision not to try to match her investment here and elsewhere. Officials in some Super Tuesday states say they still are looking for indications that he is competing in the so-called SEC primary.

A march outside a downtown Nashville coffee shop on Saturday will feature a half-dozen, life-size Bernie Sanders cutouts, but otherwise, there has been little sign of Mr. Sanders himself in Tennessee, Democrats said.

“You kind of get the feel that he doesn’t think it’s worthwhile coming,” said Randall Rice, head of the Tennessee Democratic County Chairs Association, who is neutral in the race. “The Bernie group has come in and set up offices, but he’s not been here as far as I know. Hillary has been here a few times.”

Mrs. Clinton will be back in Tennessee on Sunday.

Mr. Sanders told supporters at a Friday night rally at the Township Auditorium in Columbia that “the people have the power in this country.”

Rapper Killer Mike, who spoke at the rally, said South Carolinians—and particularly black South Carolinians—shouldn’t feel pressured to support Mrs. Clinton because others say they should, be it their mother (“Walk past her, walk to the polls”) or their preacher (“Ask him what would Jesus really do.”).

Mr. Sanders was headed to Minnesota and Texas on Saturday to trumpet his free-college-tuition plan, and he won’t be in South Carolina when the election results are announced.

Justin Bamberg, one of a handful of black legislators who endorsed Mr. Sanders in South Carolina, said he wishes the Vermont senator could stay for a victory party, but, “realistically speaking, how can you get everywhere? You can’t.”

Tharon Johnson, a Democratic strategist who served as the Southern regional director for Mr. Obama’s 2012 campaign, said the reason Mr. Sanders isn’t spending as much time in South Carolina as Mrs. Clinton “is because he now knows you have to develop a broad coalition of support in these Southern states, particularly where there’s a high minority voting-age population.”

Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said the senator’s best hope of winning South Carolina hinged on nabbing victories in Iowa, New Hampshire and Nevada, the first three contests. Mr. Sanders won the New Hampshire primary, came close in Iowa and lost Nevada. Absent an early trifecta of wins, Mr. Devine said the Sanders campaign now needs to focus on playing the long game and looking ahead to later contests.

“We still believe we have the best message, and while we had the advantage of having Iowa and New Hampshire the first and second states, she has the advantage of having so many states from the South so early in the process,” Mr. Devine said. “She’ll gain from that. Once that’s over, the ball comes back to our court and we start to move into a number of states” where they expected to do well.

Gov. Chris Christie (R., N.J.) endorsed Donald Trump for president on Friday, saying he is the Republican party's best hope to defeat Democrat Hillary Clinton in the general election. Photo: Getty

But between then and now, Mrs. Clinton is likely to secure lopsided victories that illustrate her ability to attract the diverse coalition necessary for a Democratic candidate to win the general election. She also will rack up many delegates in the process.

Mrs. Clinton broke out an all-star team of political office holders to lead statewide door-knocking in Massachusetts this weekend, in what polls suggest is one of the closest contests among the Super Tuesday states. Mrs. Clinton also plans to hold an event Boston on Monday, her campaign said.

Mrs. Clinton’s canvassing team included U.S. Sens. Ed Markey (D., Mass.) and Jeanne Shaheen (D., N.H.); Massachusetts’ popular attorney general, Maura Healey; Boston Mayor Martin J. Walsh; four U.S. House members from Massachusetts and one from Rhode Island; and former Philadelphia Mayor Michael Nutter.

Meanwhile, Mr. Sanders’s wife, Jane, disputed suggestions that she and her husband haven’t spent time in the South or have written off South Carolina or the region, attributing that narrative to what she called Clinton campaign “spin.” Mr. Sanders appeared at campaign events in the state on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday, she noted.

“They spend a lot of time spinning, and so that’s not accurate,” she said. We’ve gone to Alabama—we were down there for the 50th anniversary of Selma.”

This week, though, Mr. Sanders spent most of his time outside of the South, venturing to Massachusetts, Missouri, Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Oklahoma.

—Arian Campo-Flores and Jennifer Levitz contributed to this article.

Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com, Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com
